prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: FU Orion Band 6b
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary purpose of this setup is to simultaneously covers the gas tracers 12CO/13CO/C18O 2-1, and the dust continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Molecular gas and dust may trace different structures in the disk. We emphasize that the sensitive observations of both gas and dust emission are required to recover the full disk structures. The proposed correlator setup is modified from the standard Band 6b setup, which simultaneously covers 12CO 2-1 in baseband 1, and 13CO and C18O 2-1 in baseband 3. In addition, baseband 3 will also cover a proposed shock tracer for the protoplanetary disk, the SO 6(5)-5(4) line.
The ~0.167 km/s velocity resolution of baseband 3 is adequate for the observations of 13CO/C18O 2-1 as well as the SO line (also see the sensitivity justification). The 12CO 2-1 line in baseband 1 is covered with a high velocity resolution setup as a result of the Local Oscillator limitation. The 152 km/s velocity coverage of the 12CO 2-1 observations is sufficient for resolving the disk. The CO line is bright. The higher velocity resolution may provide more unexpected details. Therefore, we do not want to perform online spectral averaging, although the data rate may be high.
The baseband 2 and 4 will provide broad band continuum coverage. In addition, they will cover several dense cool gas and shock tracers including DCO+ 3-2, DCN 3-2, N2D+ 3-2, and SiO 5-4, with a velocity resolution of ~1.3 km/s. Such a velocity resolution is sufficient for a detection experiment. We may detect more lines. Given that the chemistry in these accretion outburst disks is largely interesting to the community, we will also not perform online spectral averaging to preserve the treasurable information.

From the Technical handbook, the 2299.6 m maximum baseline of the C36-6 configuraiton only provides 0".14 resolution at the proposed observing frequency. To achieve a comparably better resolution than our Subaru image for direct comparisons, we request observations in the long baseline, C37-7 arry configuration. This array configuration is chosen to provide high angular resolution for dust continuum imaging, while also maintaining the sensitivity to spectral lines. The best possible angular resolution of ~0".05 of this array configuration will further provide 6 beams accross the 0".3 diameter occultation mask in our Subaru image, which can address structures in the inner disk, including how the spiral arms are connecting to the protostars on small scales.
We will generate the continuum images using the best possible angular resolution of this array configuration, which is ~0".05. Thanks to this long baseline capability, the proposed linear resolution is ~2 times smaller than the resolution of our previous Subaru images (Fig. 1A), and is ~10-20 times improved over the existing SMA and ALMA data. The Subaru images have demonstrated that the proposed angular resolution is suitable for resolving spiral structures. In addition, by comparing our Subaru images (Fig. 1A) with the numerical simulations (Fig. 1E), we think the proposed dust continuum observations can marginally spatially resolve the most massive gas fragments. The proposed high resolution can also be particularly useful for unveiling structures in the inner disk, which were hindered by the occultation mask in our Subaru images.
We will smooth the spectral line images to ~0".1 angular resolution, which is comparable with the resolution of the Subaru images. Spectral line images at such resolution are adequate for diagnosing the kinematics of spiral arms and the bulk of the disk.
The existing SMA and ALMA images (Fig. 1B) suggest that the dominant gas and dust structures traced by (sub-)millimeter bands observations are smaller than ~1".5 angular scales. We have taken SMA observations on 2013 Nov. 09 and Nov. 22, which cover the 39m-228m baselines. These SMA data are excellent for combining with the proposed ALMA observations to recover the short-spacing information. On the other hand, by comparing the Subaru image (Fig. 1A) with the numerical simulations (Fig. 1E, 2), we also expect that the dominant gas structures are concentrated to the much narrower regions than the maximum recoverable scale (0".65, ~325 AU) of the proposed observations.

Line: This source is illuminated thus heated by the very actively accreting-outburst protostar, and therefore the CO isotopologues emission is expected to be bright. Based on our previous SMA observations, we are confident that the proposed RMS of ~12 K (5.22 mJy) is adequate to detect the dominant gas structures in the disk in 12CO. Considering the beam diluation of our SMA observations, and the fact that 12CO may be optically thick, we think the proposed observations can also detect 13CO, and will likely detect C18O for some dense regions. We will perform spectral smoothing for the CO isotopologues observations to 0.2 km/s velocity channels, which is typical for the observations of protostellar disk. The gravitationally accelerated gas surrounding the 0.1 Msun massive gas fragments is expect to have rotational velocities of ~+-1 km/s within a ~0.1" beam area. The proposed 0.2 km/s velocity channel can resolve such localized velocity gradient if the gas fragment is not approximately face-on).
Continuum: Our target source is bright in 1 mm dust continuum emission. Our previoius SMA observations at 230 GHz with 1".0x0".5 resolution deteccted 15 mJy dust continuum emission (Fig. 1B). The requested on-source integration time is for detecting spectral lines. The expected continuum sensitivity is adequate for resolving the disk structures for sure. Considering the typical dust opacity and gas-to-dust mass ratio of 100, the expected continuum rms noise of 32 uJy/beam will be sensitive to a fraction of Jupiter-mass of gas, which can detect gass fragments which are likely forming massive planets.
The proposed target is 3.5 degree from the bright [F(230 GHz)~1.5 Jy] calibrator 0532+075, which can be relatively easy to calibrate. We will also try self-calibration.
To preserve potentially useful information in gas kinematics and astrochemistry (see also the justification for the correlator setup), we do not want to use spectral averaging.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Z CMa Band 6b
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The primary purpose of this setup is to simultaneously covers the gas tracers 12CO/13CO/C18O 2-1, and the dust continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Molecular gas and dust may trace different structures in the disk. We emphasize that the sensitive observations of both gas and dust emission are required to recover the full disk structures. The proposed correlator setup is modified from the standard Band 6b setup, which simultaneously covers 12CO 2-1 in baseband 1, and 13CO and C18O 2-1 in baseband 3. In addition, baseband 3 will also cover a proposed shock tracer for the protoplanetary disk, the SO 6(5)-5(4) line.
The ~0.167 km/s velocity resolution of baseband 3 is adequate for the observations of 13CO/C18O 2-1 as well as the SO line (also see the sensitivity justification). The 12CO 2-1 line in baseband 1 is covered with a high velocity resolution setup as a result of the Local Oscillator limitation. The 152 km/s velocity coverage of the 12CO 2-1 observations is sufficient for resolving the disk. The CO line is bright. The higher velocity resolution may provide more unexpected details. Therefore, we do not want to perform online spectral averaging, although the data rate may be high.
The baseband 2 and 4 will provide broad band continuum coverage. In addition, they will cover several dense cool gas and shock tracers including DCO+ 3-2, DCN 3-2, N2D+ 3-2, and SiO 5-4, with a velocity resolution of ~1.3 km/s. Such a velocity resolution is sufficient for a detection experiment. We may detect more lines. Given that the chemistry in these accretion outburst disks is largely interesting to the community, we will also not perform online spectral averaging to preserve the treasurable information.

From the Technical handbook, the 2299.6 m maximum baseline of the C36-6 configuraiton only provides 0".14 resolution at the proposed observing frequency. To achieve a comparably better resolution than our Subaru image for direct comparisons, we request observations in the long baseline, C37-7 arry configuration. This array configuration is chosen to provide high angular resolution for dust continuum imaging, while also maintaining the sensitivity to spectral lines. The best possible angular resolution of ~0".05 of this array configuration will further provide 6 beams accross the 0".3 diameter occultation mask in our Subaru image, which can address structures in the inner disk, including how the spiral arms are connecting to the protostars on small scales.
We will generate the continuum images using the best possible angular resolution of this array configuration, which is ~0".05. Thanks to this long baseline capability, the proposed linear resolution is ~2 times smaller than the resolution of our previous Subaru images (Fig. 1C), and is ~20 times improved over the existing SMA data. The Subaru images have demonstrated that the proposed angular resolution is suitable for resolving spiral structures. In addition, by comparing our Subaru images (Fig. 1C) with the numerical simulations (Fig. 1E), we think the proposed dust continuum observations can marginally spatially resolve the most massive gas fragments. The proposed high resolution can also be particularly useful for unveiling structures in the inner disk, which were hindered by the occultation mask in our Subaru images.
We will smooth the spectral line images to ~0".1 angular resolution, which is comparable with the resolution of the Subaru images. Spectral line images at such resolution are adequate for diagnosing the kinematics of spiral arms and the bulk of the disk.
The existing SMA and Subaru images suggest that the dominant gas and dust structures traced by (sub-)millimeter bands observations are smaller than ~1" angular scales. We have taken SMA observations on 2013 Oct. 25 and Oct. 26, which cover the 30m-200m baselines. These SMA data are excellent for combining with the proposed ALMA observations to recover the short-spacing information. On the other hand, by comparing the Subaru image (Fig. 1C) with the numerical simulations (Fig. 1E, 2), we also expect that the dominant gas structures are concentrated to the much narrower regions than the maximum recoverable scale (0".65, ~650 AU) of the proposed observations.

Line: This source is illuminated thus heated by the very actively accreting-outburst protostar, and therefore the CO isotopologues emission is expected to be bright. Based on our previous SMA observations, we are confident that the proposed RMS of ~12 K (5.22 mJy) is adequate to detect the dominant gas structures in the disk in 12CO. Considering the beam diluation of our SMA observations, and the fact that 12CO may be optically thick, we think the proposed observations can also detect 13CO, and will likely detect C18O for some dense regions. We will perform spectral smoothing for the CO isotopologues observations to 0.2 km/s velocity channels, which is typical for the observations of protostellar disk. The gravitationally accelerated gas surrounding the 0.1 Msun massive gas fragments is expect to have rotational velocities of ~+-0.5 km/s within a ~0.1" beam area. The proposed 0.2 km/s velocity channel can resolve such localized velocity gradient if the gas fragment is not approximately face-on.
Continuum: Our target source is bright in 1 mm dust continuum emission. Our previoius SMA observations at 230 GHz with 1".0x1".0 resolution deteccted 38 mJy dust continuum emission (Fig. 1B). The requested on-source integration time is for detecting spectral lines. The expected continuum sensivity is adequate for resolving the disk structures for sure. Considering the typical dust opacity and gas-to-dust mass ratio of 100, the expected continuum rms noise of 32 uJy/beam will be sensitive to a few Jupiter-mass of gas, which can detect gass fragments which are likely forming massive planets.
The proposed target is 6.5 degree from the bright [F(230 GHz)~1.3 Jy] calibrator 0730-116, which can be relatively easy to calibrate. We will also try self-calibration.
To preserve potentially useful information in gas kinematics and astrochemistry (see also the justification for the correlator setup), we do not want to use spectral averaging.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The tremendous spiral arm features shown in our Subaru infrared polarization images towards FU Orionis objects have indicated that the disks of these accretion outburst young stellar objects (YSOs) are in an extremely unstable state. This overall picture is in excellent agreement with hydrodynamic simulations, which further suggest that the collisions of spiral-arms, and the accretion and ejection of gas fragments, play important roles for protostellar accretion and disk stabilization. Gas clumps formed in this phase may also be related to the formation of massive planets. Thanks to the new long baseline capability of ALMA, we are now able to recover the full dense gas and dust structures with a better resolution than infrared imaging. By simultaneously observing 1.3 mm dust continuum emission and the CO 2-1 isotopologues with 25-50 AU resolution, this project intends to make the first detailed outline of structures and kinematics in these disks. We will test whether the spiral features in infrared images are indeed associated with dense material arms. In addition, the proposed observations will uniquely reveal gas fragments of lower than several Jupiter masses.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
